hints.content: We can plot the numbers on a number line to compare them.

The number $\red{-29}$ is located $\red{29}$ units to the left of zero, and the number $\blue{-27}$ is located $\blue{27}$ units to the left of zero.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/096f363cdfaf8265e8230f17d3e67401b26641a3.png)

As we move to the right on the number line, numbers become larger. We can see that $\blue{−27}$ is to the right of $\red{−29}$ on the number line.
So, $\blue{-27}^\circ F > \red{-29}^\circ F$ and $ \red{-29}^\circ F < \blue{-27}^\circ F$ both show that it's colder in the North Pole.

question.content:
James lives in the North Pole. One day, when it was $-29^{\circ}\text{F}$ outside his house, James called his friend John, who lives in the South Pole, and asked how cold it was there. John said it was $-27^{\circ} F$ outside. 

**Which of the following inequalities accurately compares the temperatures in the North and South Poles?** Select all that apply.

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: We can plot the numbers on a number line to compare them.

The number $\red{-35}$ is located $\red{35}$ units to the left of zero, and the number $\blue{-45}$ is located $\blue{45}$ units to the left of zero.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3efc26c8a9bc49cd7f2d05f816d101346879538b.png)

As we move to the right on the number line, numbers become larger. We can see that $\red{−35}$ is to the right of $\blue{−45}$ on the number line.
So, $\red{-35}^\circ F > \blue{-45}^\circ F$, and $ \blue{-45}^\circ F < \red{-35}^\circ F$ both show that it's colder in the South Pole.

question.content:
John lives in the North Pole. One day, when it was $-35^{\circ}\text{F}$ outside his house, John called his friend Joan, who lives in the South Pole, and asked how cold it was there. Joan said it was $-45^{\circ} F$ outside. 

**Which of the following inequalities accurately compares the temperatures in the North and South poles?** Select all that apply.

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: We can plot the numbers on a number line to compare them.

The number $\blue{-5.8}$ is between the numbers $-5$ and $-6$. So we can plot it on the number line as follows:

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e7b7436b2850bdded022a1eabd72d76d7c0daff9.png)

The number $\red{-21}$ is located $\red{21}$ units to the left of zero.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ea5c50529799950e09ec542fa6e07fdcf4ac5376.png)

As we move to the right on the number line, numbers become larger. We can see that $\blue{−5.8}$ is to the right of $\red{−21}$ on the number line.
The inequalities $\blue{-5.8}^{\circ} F > \red{-21}^{\circ} F $ and $\red{-21}^{\circ} F < \blue{-5.8}^{\circ} F$ both show that the North Pole is colder.

question.content:
Joanne lives in the North Pole. One day, when it was $-21^{\circ}\text{F}$ outside her house, Joanne called her friend Janet, who lives in Alaska, and asked how cold it was there. Janet said it was $-5.8^{\circ} F$ outside. 

**Which of the following inequalities accurately compares the temperatures in the North Pole and Alaska?** Select all that apply.

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: We can plot the numbers on a number line to compare them.

The number $\blue{-4.7}$ is between $-4$ and $-5$. So we can plot it on the number line as follows:

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5fb89a50304f501db751d3b8ab694c0014423c9f.png)

To figure out where to put $\red{-4.77}$ on the number line remember that 

$\quad\qquad \red{-4.77} = \red{-4} + \red{-0.7} + \red{-0.07} = \red{-4.7} + \red{-0.07}$

Thus $\red{-4.77}$ is $0.07$ less than $\blue{-4.7}$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ff9617afaa8a47479c7415f68db0b87e1f120d70.png)
The inequalities $\blue{-4.7}^{\circ} F > \red{-4.77}^{\circ} F$ and $\red{-4.77}^{\circ} F < \blue{-4.7}^{\circ} F$ both show that it is colder in Newfoundland.

question.content:
Jonathan lives in Newfoundland. One day, when it was $-4.7^{\circ}\text{F}$ outside his house, Jonathan called his friend Jeremy, who lives in Alaska, and asked how cold it was there. Jeremy said it was $-4.77^{\circ} F$ outside. 

**Which of the following inequalities accurately compares the temperatures in Newfoundland and Alaska?** Select all that apply.

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: We can plot the numbers on a number line to compare them.

The number $\blue{-4.7}$ is between $-4$ and $-5$. So we can plot it on the number line as follows:

As we move to the right on the number line, numbers become larger. 
    
We can see that $\blue{−4.7}$ is to the right of $\red{−5.8}$ on the number line.
The inequalities $\blue{-4.7}^{\circ} F > \red{-5.8}^{\circ} F$ and $\red{-5.8}^{\circ} F < \blue{-4.7}^{\circ} F$ both show that it is colder in Alaska.

question.content:
Jeremy lives in Newfoundland. One day, when it was $-4.7^{\circ}\text{F}$ outside his house, Jeremy called his friend Janet, who lives in Alaska, and asked how cold it was there. Janet said it was $-5.8^{\circ} F$ outside. 

**Which of the following inequalities accurately compares the temperatures in Newfoundland and Alaska?** Select all that apply.

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: To compare fractions they must share a common denominator.
A common denominator of the two fractions $\blue{\dfrac{11}{16}}$ and $\red{\dfrac{3}{8}}$  is $16$.
To make $\red{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ have denominator 16 multiply it by $\dfrac{2}{2}$.

Multiplying $\red{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ by $\dfrac{2}{2}$ gives 

$\quad \qquad \red{\dfrac{3}{8}}\times \dfrac{2}{2} = \dfrac{\red{3}\times2}{\red{8}\times 2} =
\red{\dfrac{6}{16}}.$

Since $\blue{11} > \red{6}$ we know that $\blue{\dfrac{11}{16}} > \red{\dfrac{6}{16}}$. Since $\blue{\dfrac{11}{16}}> \red{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ we can conclude that 

 $\quad \qquad \blue{\dfrac{11}{16}} \text{cups} > \red{\dfrac{3}{8}} \text{cups}$.

question.content:
John is making noodles. To make the batter, he mixed $\dfrac{11}{16}$ cups tapioca flour with $\dfrac{3}{8}$ cups rice flour and some water. **Write an inequality to express the relationship between the tapioca flour and rice flour.**

$\dfrac{11}{16} \text{cups }$[[☃ dropdown 1]] $ \dfrac{3}{8}\text{cups}$

hints.content: First observe that $\blue{\dfrac{3}{2}}  = \blue{1\dfrac{1}{2}}$, and that $ \blue{1\dfrac{1}{2}} > 1$.
Next observe that $\red{\dfrac{3}{4}} < 1$. What can we conclude?
We can conclude that  $ \blue{\dfrac{3}{2}} > \red{\dfrac{3}{4}}$.

question.content:
John is making pasta dough. To make the dough, he mixed $\dfrac{3}{2}$ cups wheat flour with $\dfrac{3}{4}$ cups regular flour and some water. **Write an inequality to express the relationship between the wheat flour and regular flour.**

$\dfrac{3}{2} \text{cups }$[[☃ dropdown 1]] $ \dfrac{3}{4}\text{cups}$

hints.content: First observe that $\red{\dfrac{7}{15}} < 1$.
Next observe that $\blue{1\dfrac{3}{5}} > 1$. What can we conclude?
We can conclude that $\blue{1\dfrac{3}{5}} > \red{\dfrac{7}{15}} $.

question.content:
John is making pasta dough. To make the dough, he mixed $1 \dfrac{3}{5}$ cups wheat flour with $\dfrac{7}{15}$ cups regular flour and some water. **Write an inequality to express the relationship between the wheat flour and regular flour.**

$1\dfrac{3}{5} \text{cups }$[[☃ dropdown 1]] $ \dfrac{7}{15}\text{cups}$

hints.content: First observe that $\red{\dfrac{3}{2}}  = \red{1\dfrac{1}{2}}$, and $ \red{1\dfrac{1}{2}} > 1$.
But $\blue{\dfrac{3}{4}} < 1$, so what can we conclude?
We can conclude that $\blue{\dfrac{3}{4}}  < \red{\dfrac{3}{2}}$.

question.content:
John is making pasta dough. To make the dough, he mixed $\dfrac{3}{4}$ cups wheat flour with $\dfrac{3}{2}$ cups regular flour and some water. **Write an inequality to express the relationship between the wheat flour and regular flour.**

$\dfrac{3}{4} \text{cups }$[[☃ dropdown 1]] $ \dfrac{3}{2}\text{cups}$

hints.content:
The numbers $\blue{1\dfrac{1}{5}}$ and $\red{1\dfrac{1}{4}}$ both have a common whole number part. 

So to check whether $\blue{1\dfrac{1}{5}}$ is larger or smaller than $\red{1\dfrac{1}{4}}$ we need to check if $\blue{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ is smaller or larger than $\red{\dfrac{1}{4}}$.

We know that $\blue{\dfrac{1}{5}} = \blue{0.2}$ and $\red{1\dfrac{1}{4}} = \red{0.25}$. This shows us that $\blue{0.2} < \red{0.25}$.

What can we conclude?

Since $\blue{\dfrac{1}{5}} < \red{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ we conclude that  

$\quad \blue{1\dfrac{1}{5}} < \red{1\dfrac{1}{4}}.$

question.content:
John is making noodles. To make the batter, he mixed $1 \dfrac{1}{5}$ cups tapioca flour with $1 \dfrac{1}{4}$ cups rice flour and some water. **Write an inequality to express the relationship between the tapioca flour and rice flour.**

$1\dfrac{1}{5} \text{cups }$[[☃ dropdown 1]] $ 1\dfrac{1}{4}\text{cups}$

hints.content:
First observe that $\red{\dfrac{11}{16}} < \dfrac{16}{16}$. 

Since $\dfrac{16}{16} = 1$ we know that $\red{\dfrac{11}{16}} < 1$.
Next observe that $\blue{1\dfrac{3}{8}} >1$. What can we conclude?
We can conclude that $\blue{1\dfrac{3}{8}} > \red{\dfrac{11}{16}}$.

question.content:
John is making pasta dough. To make the dough, he mixed $1 \dfrac{3}{8}$ cups wheat flour with $\dfrac{11}{16}$ cups regular flour and some water. **Write an inequality to express the relationship between the wheat flour and regular flour.**

hints.content: To compare fractions they must share a common denominator.
A common denominator of the two fractions $\blue{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ and $\red{\dfrac{11}{16}}$  is $16$.
To make $\blue{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ have denominator $16$ multiply it by $\dfrac{2}{2}$.

Multiplying $\blue{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ by $\dfrac{2}{2}$ gives 

$\quad \qquad \blue{\dfrac{3}{8}}\times \dfrac{2}{2} = \dfrac{\blue{{3}}\times2}{\blue{8}\times2} =
\blue{\dfrac{6}{16}}.$

Since $\blue{6} < \red{11}$ we know that $\blue{\dfrac{6}{16}} < \red{\dfrac{11}{16}}$. Since $\blue{\dfrac{3}{8}} < \red{\dfrac{11}{16}}$ we can conclude that 

 $\quad \qquad \blue{\dfrac{3}{8}} \text{cups} < \red{\dfrac{11}{16}} \text{cups}$.

hints.content: Is $\blue{8\frac{4}{5}}$ greater than or less than $\red{8\frac{1}{2}}$?
To check whether $\blue{8\frac{4}{5}}$ is greater than or less than$\red{8\frac{1}{2}}$ we only need to check whether $\blue{\frac{4}{5}}$ is greater than or less than $\red{\frac{1}{2}}$.

We know that $\blue{\frac{4}{5}} > \frac{2.5}{5}$ and $\frac{2.5}{5} = \red{ \frac{1}{2}}$. This lets us write the inequality

$\quad \blue{8\frac{4}{5}} > \red{8\frac{1}{2}} $.

We could also write the inequality as  $\red{8\frac{1}{2}} < \blue{8\frac{4}{5}}$.
Since $\blue{8\frac{4}{5}} > \red{8\frac{1}{2}}$, Mount Everest is higher than Cho Oyu.

question.content:
The highest point on Earth, Mount Everest, is $8\frac{4}{5}\text{ km}$ high. Another mountain in the same range, Cho Oyu, is $8\frac{1}{2}\text{ km}$ high. 

**Drag the cards to write an inequality, and determine which point is higher.**

[[☃ orderer 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Mount Everest and Cho Oyu are the same height

hints.content:
Is $\blue{-10\frac{9}{10}}$ greater than or less than $\red{-5\frac{1}{2}}$? 

We can plot the numbers on a number line to compare them:

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0fb67c025116de6cea126e2fdf102d725df27213.png)

We can see that $\blue{-10\frac{9}{10}}$ is less than $\red{-5\frac{1}{2}}$. We can compare these numbers as an inequality by writing

$\quad \blue{-10\frac{9}{10}} < \red{-5\frac{1}{2}}$.

We could also write this inequality as $\red{-5\frac{1}{2}} > \blue{-10\frac{9}{10}}$.

Negative numbers represent an elevation below sea level. For example, $-1 \text{ km}$ would be $1 \text{ km}$ below sea level. When one elevation is less than another, it is lower and deeper.

Since $\blue{−10 \frac{9}{10}} <\red{-5\frac{1}{2}}$, the Mariana trench is deeper than the bottom of the Arctic Ocean.

question.content:
The deepest point on earth, the Mariana trench, is $-10\frac{9}{10}\text{ km}$ deep. (We say it is $-10\frac{9}{10}\text{ km}$ because it is $10\frac{9}{10}\text{ km}$ *below* sea level.) The bottom of the Arctic Ocean is $-5\frac{1}{2}\text{ km}$ deep.

**Drag the cards to write an inequality, and determine which point is deeper.**

[[☃ orderer 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: The bottom of the Arctic Ocean is deeper

We could also write this inequality as $\red{-7\frac{1}{8}} > \blue{-10\frac{9}{10}}$.

Negative numbers represent an elevation below sea level. For example, $-1 \text{ km}$ would be $1 \text{ km}$ below sea level. When one elevation is less than another, it is lower and deeper.

Since $\blue{−10 \frac{9}{10}} <\red{-7\frac{1}{8}}$, the Mariana trench is deeper than the Java trench.

question.content:
The deepest point on Earth, the Mariana trench,  is at $-10\frac{9}{10}\text{ km}$. ( We say it is $-10\frac{9}{10}\text{ km}$ because it is $10\frac{9}{10}\text{ km}$ *below* sea level). The deepest part of the Indian Ocean, the Java trench, is  at $-7\frac{1}{8}\text{ km}$.

Negative numbers represent an elevation below sea level. For example, $-1 \text{ km}$ would be $1 \text{ km}$ below sea level. When one elevation is less than another, it is lower and deeper.

hints.content: Is $\blue{1 \frac{3}{8}} $ greater than or less than $\red{1\frac{1}{4}}$?
$\blue{1 \frac{3}{8}} $ and $\red{1\frac{1}{4}}$ have a common whole number part. So to compare them we need check whether $\blue{\frac{3}{8}}$ is greater than or less than $\red{\frac{1}{4}}$.

Since $\blue{\frac{3}{8}} > \frac{2}{8}$ and $\frac{2}{8} = \red{\frac{1}{4}}$ we know that $\blue{\frac{3}{8}} > \red{\frac{1}{4}}$. 

This lets us write the inequality 

$\quad \blue{1 \frac{3}{8}} > \red{1\frac{1}{4}}.$

We could also write the inequality as $\red{1\frac{1}{4}} < \blue{1 \frac{3}{8}}$.
Since $\blue{1 \frac{3}{8}} > \red{1\frac{1}{4}}$, John used more than June.

hints.content: Is $\blue{\frac{15}{16}}$ greater than or less than $\red{\frac{3}{2}}$?
To check whether $\blue{\frac{15}{16}}$ is greater than or less than $\red{\frac{3}{2}}$ we can compare both numbers with $1$.

Notice that $\blue{\frac{15}{16}}<1$ and $1<\red{\frac{3}{2}}.$ This lets us write the inequality

$ \qquad\blue{\dfrac{15}{16}}<\red{\dfrac{3}{2}}$

We could also write the inequality as $\red{\frac{3}{2}} >\blue{\frac{15}{16}}$.
Since $\red{\frac{3}{2}} >\blue{\frac{15}{16}}$, Jennifer ate more than John.

Since $\blue{8\frac{4}{5}} > \red{8\frac{2}{5}}$, Mount Everest is higher than K2.

Notice that $\blue{1 \frac{5}{8}} > 1$ and $1>\red{\frac{15}{16}}$. This lets us write the inequality

We could also write the inequality as $\red{\frac{15}{16}} < \blue{1 \frac{5}{8}}$.
Since $\blue{1 \frac{5}{8}}  > \red{\frac{15}{16}}$, Jack ate more than Jolene.

hints.content: Is $\blue{1 \frac{4}{5}}$ greater than or less than $\red{1\frac{3}{8}}$?
$\blue{1 \frac{4}{5}}$ and $\red{1\frac{3}{8}}$ have a common whole number part. So to compare them we need check whether $\blue{\frac{4}{5}}$ is greater than or less than $\red{\frac{3}{8}}$.

Notice that $\blue{\frac{4}{5}} > \frac{2.5}{5}$ and $\frac{2.5}{5} = \frac{1}{2}$. This means $\blue{\frac{4}{5}} > \frac{1}{2}$.

Also $\red{\frac{3}{8}} < \frac{4}{8}$ and $\frac{4}{8} = \frac{1}{2}$. This means $\red{\frac{3}{8}} < \frac{1}{2}$.

These facts let us write the inequality $\red{\frac{3}{8}} < \blue{\frac{4}{5}}$. What can we conclude?

We can conclude that

$\quad \red{1 \frac{3}{8}}<\blue{1 \frac{4}{5}}$.

We could also write the inequality as $\blue{1 \frac{4}{5}} > \red{1 \frac{3}{8}}$.
Since $\blue{1 \frac{4}{5}} > \red{1 \frac{3}{8}}$, Jacob used more than Joshua.

question.content:

**Write an inequality to show the relationship between how much flour each person used, and determine who used more.**

[[☃ orderer 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: Jacob and Joshua used the same amount

hints.content: Is $\blue{\frac{3}{7}}$ greater than or less than $\red{\frac{5}{8}}$?
To check whether $\blue{\frac{3}{7}}$ is greater than or less than $\red{\frac{5}{8}}$ we can compare both numbers with $\frac{1}{2}$.

Notice that $\blue{\frac{3}{7}} < \frac{3.5}{7}$ and that $\frac{3.5}{7} = \frac{1}{2}$. This means $ \frac{1}{2} > \blue{\frac{3}{7}}$.

Also $\red{\frac{5}{8}} > \frac{4}{8}$ and $\frac{4}{8} = \frac{1}{2}$. This means that $\red{\frac{5}{8}} > \frac{1}{2}$.

These facts let us write the inequality

$\quad \red{\dfrac{5}{8}} > \blue{\dfrac{3}{7}} .$

We could also write the inequality as $\blue{\frac{3}{7}}  < \red{\frac{5}{8}}$.
Since $\blue{\frac{3}{7}} < \red{\frac{5}{8}}$ , Jake ate more than John.

question.content:
John and Jake made cakes. John ended up eating $\frac{3}{7}$ of a cake, and Jake ate $\frac{5}{8}$ of a cake.

**Write an inequality to show the relationship between how much each person ate, and determine who ate more.**

[[☃ orderer 1]]

choices.content: John and Jake ate the same amount

hints.content: Is  $\blue{\frac{4}{5}}$ greater than or less than $\red{\frac{3}{4}}$?

Notice that $\blue{\frac{4}{5}} = \blue{\frac{16}{20}}$ and $\red{\frac{3}{4}} = \red{\frac{15}{20}}$. Since $\blue{\frac{16}{20}} > \red{\frac{15}{20}}$ we can write the inequality

$\quad \blue{\dfrac{4}{5}} > \red{\dfrac{3}{4}}$.

We could also write the inequality as $\red{\frac{3}{4}} < \blue{\frac{4}{5}}$.
Since $\blue{\frac{4}{5}} > \red{\frac{3}{4}}$, Jennifer ate more than Jaeman.

hints.content: Is  $\blue{\frac{5}{8}}$ greater than or less than $\red{\frac{7}{8}}$?

Since $\red{7} > \blue{5}$ we can write the inequality

$\quad \red{\dfrac{7}{8}} > \blue{\dfrac{5}{8}}$.

We could also write the inequality as $\blue{\frac{5}{8}} < \red{\frac{7}{8}} $.
Since $\red{\frac{7}{8}} > \blue{\frac{5}{8}}$, Joline ate more than Jennifer.

We can see that $\blue{\frac{7}{8}} > \frac{4}{8}$ and $\frac{4}{8} = \red{\frac{1}{2}}$. This lets us write the inequality

$\quad \blue{\dfrac{7}{8}} >\red{\dfrac{1}{2}}.$

We could also write the inequality as $\red{\frac{1}{2}} < \blue{\frac{7}{8}}$.
Since $\blue{\frac{7}{8}} >\red{\frac{1}{2}}$, John ate more than Jaeman.

Compared to  the semicircular model, the rectangular model increases the air resistance of the helmet by a factor of $\dfrac{4}{\pi}$.

question.content:
Air resistance is a force on an object moving through air that reduces an object’s speed. Air resistance depends on the size and shape of an object and is directly proportional to its area.

A bicycle helmet company is choosing between two models for their racing helmets. They can choose a  semicircular helmet with a diameter of  $15 \text{ cm}$ or a rectangular helmet with length $15 \text{ cm}$ and height $7.5 \text{ cm}$. 

**When compared to  the semicircular model, by what factor does the rectangular model increase the air resistance of the helmet in terms of $\pi$?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: Let's divide the area of the rectangular model by the area of the semicircular model and simplify our fraction to compare the two models.
Compared to  the semicircular model, the rectangular model increases the air resistance of the helmet by a factor of $\dfrac{16}{3\pi}$.

question.content:
Air resistance is a force on an object moving through air that reduces an object’s speed. Air resistance depends on the size and shape of an object and is directly proportional to its area.

A bicycle helmet company is choosing between two models for their racing helmets. They can choose a  semicircular helmet with a diameter of  $12 \text{ cm}$ or a rectangular helmet with length $12 \text{ cm}$ and height $8 \text{ cm}$. 

**When compared to  the semicircular model, by what factor does the rectangular model increase the air resistance of the helmet in terms of $\pi$?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
Let's compare the areas of each model and select the shape that best models the area of a bicycle helmet. 

$\qquad\begin{align} A_{semicircle} &= \dfrac{1}{2}\pi r^2 \\\\
A_{circle} &= \pi r^2\\\\
A_{square} &= a^2\\\\
A_{rectangle} &=ab \end{align}$

We want to select a model that fits on a bicyclist's head while minimizing air resistance. A bicycle helmet fits on the top of a bicyclist's head, which is round. The greater the area, the greater the air resistance.  

A square or circle would create excess area and not make an accurate model.

Since air resistance acts in the opposite direction of an object moving through air, the front of a bicyclists helmet experiences the greatest resistance when moving. 

A semicircular model is a more accurate model than a circle to model the air resistance on the helmet.
The most accurate model for the area of a bicycle helmet is a semicircle.

question.content:
Air resistance is a force that reduces an object’s speed by acting in the opposite direction of an object moving through air.  Air resistance depends on the size and shape of an object and is directly proportional to its area. To model the air resistance for their new bicycle helmet, a company is choosing the most accurate model for the area of a bicycle helmet. 

**Choose the most accurate model for the area of a bicycle helmet.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content: Statistical questions are answered by collecting data that has variability.

*"How tall are you?"* and *"How tall is the last person who bought basketball shoes?"* **are not statistical questions.** 

Your height and the height of the last person to find basketball shoes can be found by measuring one person. Since we can measure the heights exactly, *there will not be variability in the data.*

*"How tall are people who buy basketball shoes?"* ** is a statistical question.** 

To answer this question, we need to find the heights of many people who buy basketball shoes. Since some people that buy basketball shoes will be taller and some will be shorter, *there will be variability in the data. *

Statistical questions  

- How tall are people who buy basketball shoes?

Non-statistical questions

- How tall are you?
- How tall is the last person who bought basketball shoes?

You're working at a shoe store, and you've decided to pay attention to the heights of people who buy basketball shoes.
 
**Select whether each question is statistical or not statistical.**  

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

items: How tall are people who buy basketball shoes?
How tall is the last person who bought basketball shoes?

hints.content: Statistical questions are answered by collecting data that has variability.

*"How many parts were rejected yesterday?"* **is not a statistical question.** 

This question can be answered by simply counting the number of parts rejected yesterday. Since we can count the number of parts exactly, *there will not be variability in the data.*

*"How many parts are rejected in a day?"* and *"How many parts are rejected in a week?"* **are statistical questions.**

To answer these questions, we need to find the number of parts rejected over many days and weeks. Since the number of parts rejected each day and week will not always be the same, *there will be variability in the data.*

Statistical questions  

- How many parts are rejected in a day?
- How many parts are rejected in a week?

Non-statistical questions

- How many parts were rejected yesterday?

hints.content:
A histogram groups data points together into bins and then shows how often that group happens.

The bins should be small enough so there are enough bars to show the variation in the distribution.

Histogram $B$ has a bin width of $35$ and as a result only $2$ bars.



On the other hand, Histogram $A$ has a bin width of $10$. This bin width leads to  $7$ bars which nicely shows the distribution of Aaron's number of pitches.

Histogram $A$ uses a more appropriate bin width.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/5772d9aa4e77825858adee3b89f807a38efee027.jpg)

hints.content:
The range on the vertical axis is how the frequency is measured.

 If the range is too small, the bars will go above the histogram. If the range is too large, the bars will be very small and more difficult to read.

Histogram $B$ has a range of $0-30$ which is much too large for the distribution. Notice how small the bars are and that the maximum is only at $8$.

On the other hand, Histogram $A$  has a range of $0-9$ which nicely shows the entire distribution.

Histogram $A$ uses a more appropriate range for the vertical axis.

Next, let's add up the number of putts that we do know.

$\qquad 26+39+32 = \blue{97}$ putts

$\qquad\pink{128} - \blue{97} = 31$ putts

Daniela's score was $31$ putts.

The interquartile range of the data is the difference between the two values:

$\qquad 46-38=8.$

Therefore, the interquartile range is $8\,\text{wpm}$.
The interquartile range of the typing speeds is $8\,\text{wpm}$  and the median typing speed is $42\,\text{wpm}$.

Now, in order to find the interquartile range of the values, we need to find the first and the third quartiles.

The first quartile is indicated by the left-hand edge of the box, and the third quartile is indicated by the right-hand edge of the box.

For our plot, the first quartile  is $4$, and the third quartile is $6$.

$\qquad 6-4=2.$

hints.content:

$\qquad \dfrac{3+5+4+4}{4} = \dfrac{16}{4}= \blue{4}$ kilometers

Next, let's find the distance each data point is from the mean.

Data point | Distance from the mean
:-: | :-: 
 $3$ | $\lvert3-\blue{4}\rvert = 1$
 $5$ | $\lvert5-\blue{4}\rvert = 1$
 $4$ | $\lvert4-\blue{4}\rvert = 0$

The mean absolute deviation (MAD) is the mean of the distances from the mean.

$\qquad \dfrac{1+1+0+0}{4} = \dfrac{2}{4}= 0.5$ kilometers

hints.content: The probability of drawing a joker is $0$, which tells us that it is impossible to draw a joker.
**No, it is *not* true that if you draw one card from a deck of $52$ cards, it will be a joker.** "Will be" requires that the probability is $1$.
**No, it is *not* true that you could draw a joker.** "Could" requires that the probability is greater than $0$.
**Yes, it is certain that you will not draw a joker.** A probability of $0$ means that it is certain that the event will not happen.
**No, it is *not* true that you might draw a joker.** "Might" requires that the probability is greater than $0$.

There is one true statement:  

* It is certain that you will not draw a joker.

question.content:
The probability of drawing a joker from a certain deck of $52$ cards is $0$.

[[☃ radio 1]]




![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/784497531bf3647eb1286b6d8f06f9bc75b48cf8.png)

choices.content: If you draw one card from a deck of $52$ cards, it will be a joker.
It is certain that you will not draw a joker.

hints.content: The probability of drawing an ace is $\large\frac{1}{13}$, which tells us that you might draw an ace, but it is not very likely.
**No, it is *not* true that if you draw one card from a deck of $52$ cards, it will be an ace.** "Will be" requires that the probability is $1$.
**Yes, you could draw an ace.** Any event with a probability greater than $0$ *could* happen.
**No, it is *not* certain that you will not draw an ace.** For it to be certain that you will not draw an ace, the probability must be exactly $0$.
**Yes, you might draw an ace.** Any event with a probability greater than $0$ *might* happen.

There are two true statements:  

* You could draw an ace.
* You might draw an ace.

It is certain that you will not draw an ace.

hints.content: The probability of getting snake eyes is $\large\frac{1}{36}$, which tells us that you might get snake eyes, but it is not very likely.
**Yes, it is possible that you will get snake eyes.** Any event with a probability greater than $0$ is *possible*.
**No, it is *not* true that you will never get snake eyes.** "Never" means that the probability is exactly $0$.
**Yes, you might get snake eyes.** Any event with a probability greater than $0$ *might* happen!
**No, it is *not* true that you will always get snake eyes.** "Always" requires that the probability is exactly $1$.

There are two true statements:

* It is possible that you will get snake eyes.
* You might get snake eyes.

**No, It is *not* true that the coin will land on heads for certain**. The words "for certain" require that the probability is exactly $1$.
**Yes, the coin could land on heads**. Any event with a probability greater than $0$ *could* happen.

There are two true statements:

* The coin could land on heads.

**Yes, the coin will always land on tails.** An event with a probability of $1$ will *always* happen.
**Yes, the coin will certainly land on tails.** Saying an event will "always" happen is the same as saying that it will "certainly" happen.
**No, It is *not* true that the coin will probably not land on tails.** The words "probably not" require that the probability is less than $\large\frac12$.
**No, it is *not* true that the coin will never land on tails.** "Never" requires a probability of $0$, this would mean the coin always lands on heads.

There are two true statements:

* The coin will always land on tails.
* The coin will certainly land on tails.

hints.content:
To say anything for certain with chance events, the probability must either be $0$ or $1$.

A probability of $1$ indicates that the event will certainly occur, while a probability of $0$ indicates that the event will certainly *not* occur.
An event with a probability other than $0$ or $1$ might happen or it might not.

There are two true statements:

* A chance  event with probability $1$ is certain to occur.

* A chance event with probability $0$ will certainly not occur.

question.content:
**Which of the following statements are true?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: A chance event with probability $1$ is certain to occur.
A chance event with probability $0$ will certainly not occur.
A chance event with probability $0.99999$ is certain to occur.
A chance event with probability $0.5$ is certain to occur.

hints.content:
The closer a probability is to $1$, the more likely the event.  Since $\large\frac{5}{6}$ is greater than $\large\frac{3}{4}\,$, it is true that an event with a probability of $\large\frac{5}{6}$ is more likely.

Also, the probability of an event could be $0$. In this case, it is certain that the event will *not* occur.  For example, if you roll a fair six-sided die with $1$ to $6$ dots on the faces, the probability of getting a side with $9$ dots is $0$.
It is definitely possible that you will get heads on a coin toss, and the probability of a chance event cannot be greater than $1$.  So these statements are false.

The true statement are:

* An event with a probability of $\large\frac{5}{6}$ is more likely than an event with a probability of $\large\frac{3}{4}$.

* The probability of an event could be $0$.

If you toss a fair coin, you will certainly not get heads.
The probability of a chance event is a number between $1$ and $2$.

hints.content: Since $\large\frac{3}{5}$ is less than $\large\frac{3}{4}$, an event with a probability of $\large\frac{3}{5}$  is less likely than one with a larger probability.  This statement is true.  What about the other answer choices?

The probability of a chance event is a number between $0$ and $1$, so an event cannot have a negative probability, and it cannot be a number between $1$ and $2$.  The statements that claim these are false.

There is only one true statement:  

An event with a probability of $\large\frac{3}{5}$ is less likely than an event with a probability of $\large\frac{3}{4}$.

Each square in the diagram shows two numbers.
Rolling six dice produces six numbers, so we can’t represent those outcomes with this diagram.
Rolling two dice once has the same possible outcomes as rolling a die twice in a row. They will both produce two numbers between $1$ and $6$. This diagram can be used for both of those situations.

The correct options are:

* Rolling two six-sided dice once
* Rolling a six sided die twice

choices.content: Rolling a six-sided die six times

hints.content: Each square in the diagram represents one possible outcome.
Each square in the diagram shows $2$ numbers.
Rolling $6$ four-sided dice produces $6$ numbers, so we can’t represent those outcomes with this diagram. Rolling $4$ six-sided dice also produces more than $2$ numbers.

Rolling a four-sided die and a six sided die in any order will produce one number between $1$ and $4$ and another number between $1$ and $6$, so we can represent those outcomes with this diagram.  

Notice that the order in which we roll the dice
does not matter.  A diagram with the order of the dice switched would represent the
same collection of outcomes.

**The correct options are:**

* **Rolling a six-sided die and then a four-sided die**
* **Rolling a four-sided die and then a six-sided die**

hints.content:
The  speed is the sum of the initial speed, $\blue{80}$, plus the amount the speed increases in $s$ seconds, $\green{10s}$.  The total speed after $s$ seconds is

$\qquad \blue{80}+\green{10s}$.

This must be $\pink{\text{greater than or equal to}}\, \,\purple{140}\,\text{kph}$, so the inequality is

$\qquad\blue{80}+\green{10s}\pink\geq\purple{140}$.

To solve, let's start by subtracting $\blue{80}$ from both sides of the inequality:

$\qquad\begin{align}
 80+10s&\geq140 \\\\
80+10s -\blue{{80}} &\geq 140- \blue{80} \\\\
10s &\geq 60\\
\\
\frac{{10}s}{\green{{10}}} &≥ \frac{60}{\green{10}}&(\text{divide both sides by}\,\green{10})\\
\\
s& \geq6.\end{align}$


The minimum number of seconds is therefore $6$. 

 Safe travels, Marty!

The inequality is 

$\qquad80+10s\geq 140.$

The minimum number of seconds is $6$.

question.content:
The DeLorean time machine in the film *Back to the Future* had to reach a speed of  $140\,\,\text{kph}$  in order to activate the flux capacitor, at which point  the car vanished in a great flash of light.  Let's say Marty McFly has already reached  $80\,\,\text{kph}$,  and each second, his speed increases by $10\,\,\text{kph}$. 

**Let $s$ represent the number of seconds. Write an inequality to determine how much time it will take for the DeLorean to go fast enough to activate the flux capacitor.**  
[[☃ expression 1]]

**What is the minimum whole number of  seconds it will take for the car's speed to reach $140\,\text{kph}$?**  
[[☃ numeric-input 1]] seconds

answers.message: 5 seconds isn't long enough!  Keep driving, Marty.
Marty is already gone!

**What is the sign of $19 \dfrac{72}{73}  + \left(-18 \dfrac{15}{17}\right)$?**

hints.content: We are looking for the sign of the sum of a negative number $(B)$ and a positive number $(A)$.

The negative number $(B)$ tells us to move to the left on the number line, and the positive number $(A)$ tells us to move to the right. The number that tells us to move farther determines the sign of the sum.

The absolute value (or *magnitude*) of $A$ is greater than the magnitude of $B$ because $A$ is farther from $0$.  So, $A$ determines the sign of the sum. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b0fd31877848d1ef37ec07bc20a0eca58101ece0)
The sign of the sum is positive because $A$ is positive.

hints.content:
For the first problem, subtract 6 from both sides of the equation to isolate the missing value $x$.

$\begin{align}
x+6&=-3\\\\
x+6\blue{-6}&=-3\blue{-6}\\\\
x&=-3-6\\\\
\end{align}$​

$x=\blue{-3}-6$

On the number line, start at 0 and $\blue{\text{count down 3 units}}.$

*(Insert graphie diagram here. Show number line visual, with a left-facing blue arrow counting down from 0 to -3.)*

$x=-3\blue{-6}$

Then, starting from -3, $\blue{\text{count down 6 units}}.$

*(Insert graphie diagram here. Show number line visual, with a left-facing blue arrow counting down from 0 to -3, and above that, a left facing blue arrow with a length of 6 counting up from -3 to -9. Circle the -9 on the number line, if possible)*

$x = -9$

For the second problem, add 6 to both sides of the equation to isolate the missing value $x$.

$\begin{align}
x-6&=-3\\\\
x\cancel{-6\blue{+6}}&=-3\blue{+6}\\\\
x&=-3+6\\\\
\end{align}$​

$x=\blue{-3}+6$

On the number line, start at 0 and $\blue{\text{count down 3 units}}.$

*(Insert graphie diagram here. Show number line visual, with a left-facing blue arrow counting down from 0 to -3.)*

$x=-3\blue{+6}$

Then, starting from -3, $\blue{\text{count up 6 units}}.$

*(Insert graphie diagram here. Show number line visual, with a left-facing blue arrow counting down from 0 to -3, and above that, a right facing blue arrow with a length of 6 counting up from -3 to +3. Circle the 3 on the number line, if possible)*

$x = 3$

hints.content:
Subtraction is the same as adding the opposite.  

$x$ is a negative number, so its opposite is a positive number.   
$\purple{0-x} = 0+ ($opposite of  $x)$  
$\qquad\:= 0+($positive number$)$  
$\qquad\:= ($positive number$)$  

$\purple{0-x}$ is $\red{\text{positive}}$.

$\qquad\quad\:= ($positive number$) + ($positive number$)$  
$\qquad\quad\:= ($positive number$)$

hints.content:
Think of a rabbit standing on a number line.  When we look at the expression:  
$\qquad \blue{x}\pink{-}\green{(-x)}$

- The first term tells the rabbit to stand at $\blue{x}$.  
- The $\pink{\text{minus sign}}$ tells the rabbit to face in the negative, or $\pink{\text{left}}$, direction.
- The $\green{-x}$ tells the rabbit which direction to go and how far.  
Because $\green{-x}$ is a $\green{\text{positive}}$ number, the rabbit will move in the $\green{\text{direction she is facing}}$, so she will move to the $\green{\text{left}}$.  
The distance she will move is $\green{|-x|}$, which is the same as the distance from $0$ to $\green{-x}$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1935b979af1a4f216b889c5aadcf6f4ae267bc18.png)

We can see that  $\red{x-(-x)}$ is to the left of $0$.

$(x-(-x))<0$

question.content:
You’re building your own bookcase out of a sturdy oak wood. When you try to gauge where to put a shelf, your initial estimate is $\dfrac{1}{12}$ of a meter too high. 

**What change in height will put the shelf where you’d like it to be?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] meters

hints.content: The ground is at a height of $0$.
Your height is greater than $0$, so we will need to decrease height to get from $\red{150.3}$ to $0$.
The additive inverse of $\red{150.3}$ is the number that, when added to $\red{150.3}$, produces $0$.
The additive inverse of $\red{150.3}$ is $\green{-150.3}$.
You need to change your altitude by $\green{-150.3}$ meters to get back to the ground.

question.content:
Pilots use negative numbers to represent decreasing altitude, and positive numbers to represent increasing altitude.


You’re piloting a hot air balloon, and the balloon is flying at an altitude of $150.3$ meters above the ground. 

**By how many meters do you need to change your altitude to get back to the ground?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] meters

hints.content: If we think of the cruising altitude as $0$, then the plane is currently at $\red{-0.61}$ because of the turbulence.

hints.content:
Think of a rabbit standing on a number line.  When we look at the expression:  
$\qquad \blue{-y}\pink{-}\green{x}$

- The first term tells the rabbit to stand at $\blue{-y}$.  
- The $\pink{\text{minus sign}}$ tells the rabbit to face in the negative, or $\pink{\text{left}}$, direction.
- The $\green{x}$ tells the rabbit which direction to go and how far.  
Because $\green{x}$ is $\green{\text{positive}}$, the rabbit will move in the $\green{\text{direction she is facing}}$, so she will move to the $\green{\text{left}}$.  
The distance she will move is $\green{|x|}$, which is just $\green{x}$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c37fcdb9af1e150c7f49bc31723dee73f9e4106e.png)

The correct answer is:  
Start at $\blue{-y}$ and move $\green{x}$ units to the left.

hints.content:
Think of a rabbit standing on a number line.  When we look at the expression:  
$\qquad \blue{y}\pink{-}\green{(-x)}$

- The first term tells the rabbit to stand at $\blue{y}$.  
- The $\pink{\text{minus sign}}$ tells the rabbit to face in the negative, or $\pink{\text{left}}$, direction.
- The $\green{-x}$ tells the rabbit which direction to go and how far.  
Because $\green{-x}$ is $\green{\text{negative}}$, the rabbit will move in the $\green{\text{opposite}}$ of the direction she is facing, so she will move to the $\green{\text{right}}$.  
The distance she will move is $\green{|-x|}$, which is just $\green{x}$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cdf6c728cdefe3a4f6da22d510084193b8b9f488.png)

The correct answer is:  
Start at $\blue{y}$ and move $\green{x}$ units to the right.

hints.content:
Think of a rabbit standing on a number line.  When we look at the expression:  
$\qquad \blue{-x}\pink{-}\green{x}$

- The first term tells the rabbit to stand at $\blue{-x}$.  
- The $\pink{\text{minus sign}}$ tells the rabbit to face in the negative, or $\pink{\text{left}}$, direction.
- The $\green{x}$ tells the rabbit which direction to go and how far.  
Because $\green{x}$ is $\green{\text{positive}}$, the rabbit will move in the $\green{\text{direction she is facing}}$, so she will move to the $\green{\text{left}}$.  
The distance she will move is $\green{|x|}$, which is just $\green{x}$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/273159eae59090b8638e898db66f4ed6f200efb7.png)

The correct answer is:    
Start at $\blue{-x}$ and move $\green{x}$ units to the left.

question.content:

choices.content: Start at $-x$ and move $x$ units to the right.
Start at $-x$ and move $x$ units to the left.
Start at $-x$ and move right to the number $x$.
Start at $-x$ and stay in the same place.

question.content:
The lacrosse team at Shady Pines Middle School is on a long bus ride to their next game. 

To pass the time, the team decides to roll two dice $1000$ times and record the sums of the two dice. For example, if they rolled a $3$ and a $4$, they would record a sum of $7$. The results are in the table below.


**Use this data to estimate  the probability  of getting a sum of $10$ when two dice are rolled. Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest hundredth.
** 

$\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]]

Sum | Number of times rolled| 
:-: | :-: | -
$2$ | $35$ | 
$3$ | $56$| 
$4$| $59$ | 
$5$|$109$
$6$|$143$
$7$|$180$
$8$|$120$
$9$|$111$
$10$|$86$
$11$|$61$
$12$|$40$

question.content:
Roulette  is a game of chance that originated in France in the eighteenth century.   The roulette wheel is spun, and a small white ball is dropped into the wheel.  When the wheel stops, the ball lands on a number between $0$ and $36$, inclusive.  The numbers from $1$ to $36$ are red or black, and $0$ is green.

In $500$ spins of a roulette wheel, the ball landed on red $230$ times.
 

**Use the data to estimate the probability  that the ball will land on red on the next spin. Express your answer as a decimal rounded to the nearest hundredth.
**

$\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]]


![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/43f1fee3ac2bd95fbe360cda76bc720dd06c0937.jpeg)

hints.content: A sum of $8$ or more will occur if a sum of $8$, $9$, $10$, $11$, or $12$ is rolled. How many times did these outcomes occur?

Let's add $125$, $116$, $86$, $66$, and $40$ to get $433$ outcomes of a sum of $8$ or more out of $1000$ trials.  


Based on the data, the relative frequency of a sum of $8$ or more is $\dfrac{433}{1000}$.  If we convert this to a decimal and round to the nearest hundredth, we get $0.43$.
**Based on this data, we can estimate the probability of getting a sum of $8$ or more as  $0.43$.**

question.content:
The probability of selecting a heart from a deck of $52$ cards is $\dfrac14$.

**If one card is selected at random from each of $300$ decks, approximately how many hearts can we reasonably expect to draw? Round your answer to the nearest whole number.
**

$\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]]

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/d495221104291cf7603f3705179849c0d26a6713.jpeg)

hints.content: We expect the ball to land on $0$ roughly $\dfrac{1}{37}$ of the $1000$ spins.
Since $\dfrac{1}{37}\cdot1000=27$ after rounding to the nearest whole number, we can expect the ball to land on $0$ about $27$ times.

question.content:
Roulette  is a game of chance that originated in France in the eighteenth century.   The roulette wheel is spun, and a small white ball is dropped into the wheel.  When the wheel stops, the ball lands on a number between $0$ and $36$, inclusive.

The probability of the ball landing on $0$ is $\dfrac{1}{37}$. 

**In $1000$ spins of a roulette wheel, approximately how many times can you reasonably expect the ball to land on $0$? Round your answer to the nearest whole number.
**

$\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]]

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/43f1fee3ac2bd95fbe360cda76bc720dd06c0937.jpeg)

hints.content: When we flip a coin $1200$ times, we can expect the coin to land on tails approximately $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of the time.
Since $\dfrac{1}{2}\cdot1200=600,$ we can expect to get about $600$ heads.

question.content:
The probability of a fair coin landing on heads is $\dfrac12$. 

**If a fair coin is flipped $1200$ times, approximately how many times can we reasonably expect the coin to land on heads?**

$\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]]

question.content:
The probability of selecting an ace from a deck of $52$ cards is $\dfrac1{13}$.

**

question.content:
When rolling a pair of fair six-sided dice, the probability of rolling a sum of $12$ is $\dfrac{1}{36}$.

**If a pair of fair six-sided dice is rolled $200$ times, approximately how many times can we reasonably expect to roll a sum of $12$? Round your answer to the nearest whole number.
**

$\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]]

Debits are represented by negative numbers, so John's account has $-16$ dollars.

$\qquad |12 - (-16)| = |12 + 16| = 28$ dollars
Sabrina's account has $28$ more dollars.

Since $\dfrac{-3}{a}>0$, 

$\qquad 4\times\dfrac{-3}{a}>0.$



Next,  $4\times-3<0$, so that


$\qquad \dfrac{4\times -3}{a}>0.$ 



What about the other choices?

Since  $a$ is negative,  $\dfrac4a$ is also negative; it is the quotient of a positive and a negative number.  Therefore


$\qquad \dfrac4a\div 3<0.$ 



We see that  $\dfrac a{-4}>0,$  so 

$\qquad  -3\div \dfrac a{-4} <0.$

Positive: 



*  $\dfrac{4\times -3}{a}$ 

*  $4\times\dfrac{-3}{a}$

Negative:

$\qquad\text{positive}\times\text{negative}=\text{negative}$

$\qquad\text{negative}\times\text{positive}=\text{negative}$

With this in mind, we see that 

$\qquad 2\times \dfrac12\,$   and 
$ -2\times -\dfrac12$ 

are positive, and the other two choices are negative.

Positive: 

* $\,\,\,\,\,2\times \dfrac12$

* $-2\times -\dfrac12$  


Negative:

* $2\,\,\,\,\,\times -\dfrac 12$

* $-2\times \dfrac 12$

Let's write an expression for the first situation and see if it matches the given expression. 

Zack ate $3$ cookies, so we start with $-3$.

Putting this together gives us the expression $-3+7$, which is not the same as the given expression.

Now, let's write an expression for the second situation and see if it matches the given expression. 

Zack's mom adding $3$ cookies tells us to start with $3$. 

We show that $7$ cookies disappear with $-7$.

Putting this together gives us the expression $3-7$, which is the same as the given expression.

question.content:
## getting too wordy

#Prefer \text{ m} to meters.

#In the first line we say water level but after that we just say level. Better to stay consistent by always saying water level so for example, the last part of the last sentence would say "figure out the current water level of the lake."

#Also is this how folks that talk about water levels talk about them? I have no idea but 200 m seems like a really big water level. 

#I'm also a bit confused that students won't understand what water level means. It makes things wordier but something like "Biologists consider the water level of a lake to be the distance between the ground to the top of the water."

#Lastly, again I don't know anything about water levels but maybe we should be talking about a specific spot like the center of the lake?

hints.content:
Let's use the formula to find the value of Diana's investment:

Value of investment $=\blue{S} \cdot(\purple{1.07})^{\red{n}}$.

The initial investment is $\blue{S=10000}$ dollars and we're asked to find the value of the investment after $\red{n=4}$ years.

Let's substitute $\blue{S=10000}$ and $\red{n=4}$ into the formula and evaluate. We can use the calculator to calculate the value.

$\begin{align*}
\blue{10000} \cdot \left(\purple{1.07}\right)^{\red{4}} 
 & =\blue{10000}\left( 1.07\cdot 1.07\cdot 1.07\cdot 1.07 \right) \\
 & =\blue{10000} \left( 1.310796 \right)  \\
 & = 10000 \cdot 1.310796 \\
 & =13107.96
\end{align*}$
After $\red{4}$ years the investment will have grown to $\$13{,}107.96$.

question.content:
Diana is considering making an investment with a company which offers a return rate of $7\%$ per year. If she invests an initial sum of $S$ dollars, her investment will grow according to the formula $S\cdot (1.07)^n$ where $n$ is the number of years.

hints.content:
Let's first look at the formula for calculating the total length of line segments that remain when Georg starts with a line segment of length $\gray{\ell}$ and uses the eraser $\purple{n}$ times. 

Total length of line segments remaining  $=\gray{\ell}\cdot\left(\blue{\dfrac{2}{3}} \right)^{\purple{n}}$

Let's now use this formula to calculate the total length of line segments that remain after Georg repeats the eraser procedure $\purple{n=3}$ times starting from a line with length $\gray{\ell}=\gray{27}\text{ cm}$.

The total length of line segments remaining is given by the expression:

$\begin{align*}
\gray{\ell}\cdot\left(\blue{\frac{2}{3}} \right)^{\purple{n}}
 &=\gray{27}\cdot\left(\blue{\frac{2}{3}}\right)^{\purple{3}}  \\[1mm]
 &= \gray{27} \cdot\left(\blue{\frac{2}{3}}\cdot\blue{\frac{2}{3}}\cdot\blue{\frac{2}{3}}\right)   \\[1mm]
 &= \gray{27} \cdot \dfrac{8}{27}  \\[1mm]
 &=  8
\end{align*}$

So the total length of the line segments remaining is 
$8\text{ cm}$.

hints.content:
The *sum* of two terms means we are adding two terms. 

*Terms* are single numbers, variables, or the product of a number and variable.

$\blue{a}$ is a variable and $\blue{7}$ is a single number so they are each a term. So, $\blue{a+7}$ is the sum of two terms.
The *product* of two terms means we are multiplying two terms. $\blue{(a+7)}$ is addition so it’s a sum, not a product.
The *factors* of a product are the numbers that are being multiplied. In this expression, $\red{3}$ is being multiplied by $\blue{(a+7)}$, so  $\blue{a+7}$ is one of the factors.

$\blue{a+7}$ is 

*  the sum of two terms.
*  one of the factors of a product.

hints.content:
*Terms* are single numbers, variables, or the product of a number and variable. 

$\red{2}\blue{c}$ is the product of a number and a variable so it is a term.
A *product* is the result of multiplying. $\red{2}$ and $\blue{c}$ are being multiplied by each other, so $\red{2}\blue{c}$ is a product.

A *factor* is one part of a product.

In this expression, $\red{2}$ is being multiplied by $\blue{c}$, so they are each factors of the product $\red{2}\blue{c}$.

$\red{2}\blue{c}$ is

*  a term.
*  a product.

hints.content:
The *difference* of two terms means we are subtracting one term from another. 

*Terms* are single numbers, variables, or the product of a number and variable.

$\red{9}$ is a single number and $\blue{c}$ is a variable, and $\blue{c}$ is being subtracted from $\red{9}$. So, $\red{9}-\blue{c}$ is the difference of two terms.
The *product* of two terms means we are multiplying two terms. $\red{9}-\blue{c}$ is subtraction so it’s a difference, not a product.

A *factor* is one part of a product.

In this expression, $\purple{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ is being multiplied by $(\red{9}-\blue{c})$, so $\red{9}-\blue{c}$  is one of the factors.

$\red{9}-\blue{c}$ is  

* the difference of two terms.
*  one of the factors of a product.

hints.content:
Let's create an expression for when Alex orders $\blue{n}$ rolls at his favorite sushi restaurant. 


Alex pays a base charge of $\$\pink{5}$ for tea and miso soup plus $\$\purple{2}$ per sushi roll ordered. How much does he pay when he orders $\green{1}$ roll of sushi?

When Alex orders one sushi roll, or $\blue{n}=\green{1}$, we combine the base charge plus the price for one sushi roll. From the table, Alex pays $\pink{5}+\purple{2}\cdot \green{1}$.

How much does Alex pay if he orders  $\blue{n}=\gray{2}$ rolls of sushi?

Alex pays $\pink{5}+\purple{2}\cdot \gray{2}$.

The price calculation works the same way for *any* number of rolls. We start with the base price of $\pink{5}$ dollars and add $\purple{2}$ times the number of sushi rolls $\blue{n}$.
The expression which describes the price of $\blue{n}$ sushi rolls at Alex's favorite restaurant is $\pink{5}+\purple{2}\blue{n}$.

Number of sushi rolls | Price

$0$ | $5+2\cdot 0$
$1$ | $5+2\cdot 1$
$2$ | $5+2\cdot 2$
$3$ | $5+2\cdot 3$

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to $8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$.

Let's take each option one by one:

$8^4 =8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$

$\blue{8^3}\cdot\green{8^1} = (\blue8\cdot\blue8\cdot\blue8)(\green8) = 8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$

$\pink{8^4}\cdot\gray{8^1} =(\pink8\cdot\pink8\cdot\pink8\cdot\pink8)(\gray8) = 8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$

$\dfrac{1}{8^{-4}}=8^4 = 8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$

Equivalent to $ 8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$:

- $\dfrac{1}{8^{-4}}$

Not equivalent to $ 8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$:

question.content:
**Choose the expressions that are equivalent to $8\cdot8\cdot8\cdot8$.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to  $\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}$ .

Let's take each option one by one:

$12^{3} = 12\cdot12\cdot12$

$12^7 = 12\cdot12\cdot12\cdot12\cdot12\cdot12\cdot12$

$\begin{align}\left(\dfrac{1}{12}\right)\^{\Large3}&= \dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12} \end{align}$

$\begin{align}\dfrac{1}{12\^{\Large3}}&=\dfrac{1}{12\cdot12\cdot12}\\
&= \dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12} \end{align}$

Equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}$ :

- $\left(\dfrac{1}{12}\right)\^{\Large3}$  


- $\dfrac{1}{12\^{\Large3}}$

Not equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}\cdot\dfrac{1}{12}$ : 

- $12^{3}$
- $12^7$

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to  $\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}$ .

Let's take each option one by one:

$4^{3} = 4\cdot4\cdot4$

$\begin{align}4^{-3}&= \dfrac{1}{4^3} \\
&=\dfrac{1}{4\cdot4\cdot4}\\
\\
&= \dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\\
\\
\\
\left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)\^{\Large3} &=\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\\
\\
\\
\dfrac{1}{4\^{\Large3}}&=\dfrac{1}{4\cdot4\cdot4}\\
\\
&= \dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}
 \end{align}$

Equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}$ :

- $4^{-3}$

- $\left(\dfrac{1}{4}\right)\^{\Large3}$


- $\dfrac{1}{4\^{\Large3}}$

Not equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}$ : 

- $4^{3}$

question.content:
**Choose the expressions that are equivalent to  $\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}\cdot\dfrac{1}{4}$ .**

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}$ .

Let's take each option one by one:

$\begin{align} 3^{-4}&=\dfrac{1}{{3}\^{\Large4}}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot3}\\
\\
&=\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\\
\\
3^\blue{-2}\cdot3^\green{-2}&=\dfrac{1}{{3}\^{\Large\blue2}}\cdot\dfrac{1}{{3}\^{\Large\green2}}\\
\\
&=\dfrac{1}{\blue3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{\blue3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{\green3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{\green3}
\end{align}$

$\begin{align}\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\^{\Large{-4}}&=3^4\\
&=3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot3\end{align}$

$\begin{align}\dfrac{1}{3\^{\Large{-4}}}&=3^4\\
&=3\cdot3\cdot3\cdot3\end{align}$

Equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}$ :

- $3^{-4}$
- $3^{-2}\cdot3^{-2}$

Not equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}$ : 

- $\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\^{\Large{-4}}$


- $\dfrac{1}{3\^{\Large{-4}}}$

question.content:

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to:

  $\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}$

Because there are an even number of negative numbers, they will cancel each other out.  So the expression is also equal to:

$\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}$

Let's take each option one by one:

$(-9)^{4} = (-9)\cdot(-9)\cdot(-9)\cdot(-9)$

$\begin{align}9^{-4}&= \dfrac{1}{9^4} \\
&=\dfrac{1}{9\cdot9\cdot9\cdot9}\\
\\
&= \dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}  \end{align}$

$\begin{align}-\left(\dfrac{1}{9}\right)\^{\Large4} &=-\left(\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\right)\\
\end{align}$

$\begin{align}\dfrac{1}{9\^{\Large4}}&=\dfrac{1}{9\cdot9\cdot9\cdot9}\\
&= \dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9}\cdot\dfrac{1}{9} \end{align}$

Equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}$ :


- $9^{-4}$
- $\dfrac{1}{9\^{\Large4}}$

Not equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-9)}$ : 

- $(-9)^{4}$


- $-\left(\dfrac{1}{9}\right)\^{\Large4}$

question.content:

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to:

 $\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}$

This expression can also be written like this:



$-\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\right)$

Let's take each option one by one:

$\begin{align} 3^{-3}&=\dfrac{1}{{3}\^{\Large3}}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{3\cdot3\cdot3}\\
\\
&=\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\end{align}$

$\begin{align} (-3)^{-3}&=\dfrac{1}{{(-3)}\^{\Large3}}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{(-3)\cdot(-3)\cdot(-3)}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\end{align}$

$\begin{align} -\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^{\large3}&= -\left(\dfrac{1}{{3}\^{\Large3}}\right)\\
 \\
&=-\left(\dfrac{1}{3\cdot3\cdot3}\right)\\
\\
&=-\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\cdot\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\end{align}$


$\begin{align} \left(-\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^{3}&= \dfrac{1}{{(-3)}\^{\Large3}}\\
&= \dfrac{1}{(-3)\cdot(-3)\cdot(-3)}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\end{align}$

Equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}$ :

- $(-3)^{-3}$


- $-\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\^{\Large3}$


- $-\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)\^{\Large3}$

Not equivalent to$\:\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-3)}$ : 

- $3^{-3}$

hints.content:
We are looking for expressions equivalent to:

 $\qquad\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}$

This expression can also be written like this:



$\qquad-\dfrac{1}{8}\cdot-\dfrac{1}{8}\cdot-\dfrac{1}{8}$

Let's take each option one by one:

$\begin{align} 8^{-3}&=\dfrac{1}{{8}\^{\Large3}}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{8\cdot8\cdot8}\\
\\
&=\dfrac{1}{8}\cdot\dfrac{1}{8}\cdot\dfrac{1}{8}\end{align}$

$\begin{align} (-8)^{-3}&=\dfrac{1}{{(-8)}\^{\Large3}}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{(-8)\cdot(-8)\cdot(-8)}\\
&=\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\end{align}$

$\begin{align} -\left(\dfrac{1}{8}\right)^{3}&= -\left(\dfrac{1}{{8}\^{\Large3}}\right)\\
\\
&=-\left(\dfrac{1}{8\cdot8\cdot8}\right)\\
\\
&=-\left(\dfrac{1}{8}\cdot\dfrac{1}{8}\cdot\dfrac{1}{8}\right)\end{align}$

$\begin{align} \left(-\dfrac{1}{8}\right)^{3}&= \dfrac{1}{{(-8)}\^{\Large3}}\\
&= \dfrac{1}{(-8)\cdot(-8)\cdot(-8)}\\
\\
&=\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\end{align}$

Equivalent to $\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}\cdot\dfrac{1}{(-8)}$ :

- $(-8)^{-3}$

- $8^{-3}$

hints.content:
In the expression $(-2)^3$, we multiply a negative number an odd number of times $(3)$, so the result will be negative. Since $-2$ is less than $-1$, the result will be less than $-1$.

The same is true for $(-2)^5$.

$\qquad2^{{-4}} = \dfrac{1}{2^4} = \dfrac{1}{2\cdot2\cdot2\cdot2}$

In this expression, we divide $1$ by a positive number greater than $1$, so the result must be between $0$ and $1$.

The same is true for $(-2)^{{-4}}$ and the negative number is multiplied a even number of times, $4$, so the result will be positive.

$\qquad(-2)^{{-4}} =\dfrac{1}{(-2)^{4}} = \dfrac{1}{(-2)\cdot(-2)\cdot(-2)\cdot(-2)}$
In the expression $(-2)^4$, we multiply a negative number an even number of times $(4)$, so the result will be positive. Since $-2$ is less than $-1$, the result will be greater than $1$.

Category | Expressions
- | - | -
Less than $-1$| $(-2)^5$, $(-2)^{3}$
Between $0$ and $1$ | $2^{-4}, (-2)^{-4}$
Greater than $1$ | $(-2)^4$

hints.content:
Recall the property of exponents:   $\Large{a^\red {{x}} \cdot a^\blue {{y}} = a^{\red {{x}} + \blue {{y}}}}$.  

So,    
$\Large\begin {align}\qquad 2^{\red {-6}} \cdot 2^{\blue 5}&=2^{(\red {-6} + \blue 5)}\\
&=\underbrace{2^{\purple {-1}}}  \\
&=~~2^{\purple {\large{a}}}
\end{align}$  

Therefore,     
$\qquad \purple a=  \purple {-1}$.

Recall the property of exponents: $\Large\left(a^\red {{x}}\right)^\blue {{y}} = \Large{a^{\red {{x}} \cdot \blue {{y}}}}$.

So,  
$\Large\begin{align} \qquad\left(2^{\red {-6}}\right)^{\blue 5}&= 2^{\red {-6} \cdot \blue 5}\\
&= \underbrace{2 ^ {\purple{-30}}}\\
&=~~2^\purple {{b}}
\end{align}$

Therefore,  
$\qquad \purple b=\purple{-30}$.

Let's try to find the value of $c$ such that $\Large(12)^{-6}=3^{\large{c}}\cdot4^{\large{c}}$.  


$\Large\begin{align}\qquad(12)^{-6}&=(3\cdot4)^{-6}\\
&=3^{-6} \cdot 4^{-6}\\
&=\overbrace{3^{\large{c}}\cdot4^{\large{c}}}
\end{align}$

So,  
$\qquad c=-6$.

$\qquad a= -1$  
$\qquad b= -30$  
$\qquad c= -6$

**Write $\Large\left(7^{-3} \cdot 2^{-3}\right)^{4}$ in the form $\Large14^{^{\scriptstyle{y}}}$, where $y$ is an integer.**

[[☃ expression 1]]

options.placeholder: This answer area is being deprecated. Please use the widgets in the question area for your answer.

hints.content:
First let's simplify what's inside the parentheses using the property 

$\Large{\qquad a^{{x}} \cdot b^{{x}} = (a\cdot b)^{{x}}}$.  

So,   
$\begin{align}\qquad\left(\large\purple {7^{-3} \cdot 6^{-3}}\right)^{4} &= \left(\large\purple{(7\cdot6)^{-3}}\right)^{4}\\
&=\left(\large{42^{-3}}\right)^{4}.\\
\end{align}$

Now let's use the property 

$\Large\qquad\left(b^{{x}}\right)^{\large{y}}=b^{(x \cdot y)}$.

So,  
$\Large\begin{align}\qquad\left(42^{-3}\right)^{4} &= 42^{(-3\cdot4)}\\
&= 42^{-12}
\end{align}$
$\Large\qquad \left(7^{-3} \cdot 6^{-3}\right)^{4}  = 42^{-12}$

question.content:
**Write $\Large{\left(7^{-3} \cdot 6^{-3}\right)^{4}}$ in the form $\Large42^{^{\scriptstyle{y}}}$, where $y$ is an integer.**

hints.content:
When a number is multiplied by a negative power of $10$, the exponent tells us how many times the number is divided by $10$:

$10^{\green{-2}}=1\green{\div10\div10}=\green{0.01}$

In the number $7\times10^{-6}$, how many times is $7$ divided by $10?$

In the number $7×10^{−6}$, $7$ is divided by $10$ six times, so the diameter of a red blood cell is approximately $0.000007$ meters:

$7×10^{\blue{−6}}=7\blue{÷10÷10÷10÷10÷10÷10}=0.000007$

Which of the choices is approximately equal to $0.000007?$

If we round the numbers in the choices to the largest nonzero digit, we can see that $0.00000681$ rounds to $0.000007$:

$0.00000681$  
$\phantom{xxxxi}\Downarrow$  
$\blue{0.000007}$

So the diameter of a red blood cell could be $0.00000681$ meters.

To find out how much thinner the needle would have had to be to draw blood one cell at a time, we need to figure out how many times as small the diameter of a red blood cell $(7\times10^{-6})$ is as the diameter of the last needle that stabbed Niles $(7\times10^{-4})$.

$7\times10^{-6}$ is the same as $7$ divided by $10$ six times, and $7\times10^{-4}$ is the same as $7$ divided by $10$ four times, so $7\times10^{-6}$ is divided by $10$ two more times than $7\times10^{-4}$.

$10^{-4}={1\div10\div10\div10\div10}$  
$10^{-6}={1\div10\div10\div10\div10}\green{\div10\div10}$  
$10^{-6}={10^{-4}}\green{\div10\div10}$  

$10^{-6}$ is $\green{\dfrac1{100}}$ times as large as  $10^{-4}$, so $7\times10^{-6}$ is $\green{\dfrac1{100}}$ times as large as $7\times10^{-4}$.
So the needle would have to be $\green{\dfrac1{100}}$ times as thick to draw blood only one cell at a time.

- The diameter of a red blood cell could be $0.00000681$ meters.
- The needle would have to be $\dfrac1{100}$ times as thick in order to draw blood only one cell at a time.

hints.content:
When a number is multiplied by a positive power of $10$, the exponent tells us how many times the number is multiplied by $10$:

$10^{\green2}=1\green{\times10\times10}=\green{100}$  
$10^{\purple3}=1\purple{\times10\times10\times10}=\purple{1000}$
How many times is $8$ multiplied by $10$ in $8\times10^7?$  How many times is $2$ multiplied by $10$ in $2\times10^4?$

$8\times10^7$ is $8$ multiplied by $10$ seven times, and $2\times10^4$ is $2$ multiplied by $10$ four times, so $8\times10^7$ is multiplied by $10$ three more times than $2\times10^4$.

$10^4=\blue{10\times10\times10\times10}$  
$10^7=\blue{10\times10\times10\times10}\red{\times10\times10\times10}$   
$10^7=\blue{10^4}\red{\times10\times10\times10}$

So $10^4$ is $\red{\dfrac{1}{1000}}$ times as large as $10^7$.
$2$ is $\red\dfrac14$ times as large as $8$, so $2\times10^4$ is $\red{\dfrac14\times\dfrac1{1000}}$ times as large as $8\times10^7$.
$2\times10^4$ is $\dfrac1{4000}$ times as large as $8\times10^7$.

hints.content:
When a number is multiplied by a positive power of $10$, the exponent tells us how many times the number is multiplied by $10$:

$10^{\pink1}=1\pink{\times10}=\pink{10}$  
$10^{\green2}=1\green{\times10\times10}=\green{100}$  
$10^{\purple3}=1\purple{\times10\times10\times10}=\purple{1000}$
How many times is $4$ multiplied by $10$ in the number $4\times10^5?$

In the number $4\times10^5$, $4$ is multiplied by $10$ five times:

$4\times10^{\blue5}=4\blue{\times10\times10\times10\times10\times10}$

We can also break down the number $200$ this way:

$200=2\times10\times10$

So $200=2\times10^2$.

What number can be multiplied by $2$, then multiplied by $10$ two times to get $4\times10^5?$

$\red2$ can be multiplied by $2$ to get $4$.  
$\red{10^3}$ can be multiplied by $10$ two times to get $10^5$:

$10^3=\red{10\times10\times10}$  
$10^5=\red{10\times10\times10}\blue{\times10\times10}$  
$10^5=\red{10^3}\times\blue{10^2}$

Putting these numbers together, we get:

$(\red{2\times10^3})\times(2\times10^2)=4\times10^5$
$4\times10^5$ is $200$ times as large as  $2\times10^3$.

The correct answer is:

- $2\times10^3$, or $2000$.

hints.content: We know that rational numbers can be expressed as fractions, or as ratios of two integers.  Which of the answer choices can be expressed that way?
$6\dfrac{1}{2}=\dfrac{13}{2}$ , so $6\dfrac{1}{2}$ is rational.
$9.0=\dfrac{9}{1}$ , so it is also rational.

Every real number can be expressed as a decimal. Decimals that terminate $\big($like $0.75\big)$ or eventually repeat $\big($like $0.333...=0.\overline{3}\big)$ can be represented by fractions, so they are rational. $\bigg($We can divide to see that $0.75 = \dfrac{3}{4}$ and $ 0.333...=\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg)$.
$7.11$ is a terminating decimal, so it is a rational number. We can also see that it's rational because it can be represented as a fraction: $7.11 = 7\dfrac{11}{100}=\dfrac{711}{100}$.

Square roots of numbers that are perfect squares $\big($like $9=3^2$ or $16=4^2\big)$ are rational numbers, but square roots of numbers that are not perfect squares are irrational. $32=16\cdot2$ is  not a perfect square, so $\sqrt{32}$ is irrational. We can also see that $\sqrt{32}=4\sqrt{2}$ is the product of a rational number $(4)$ and an irrational number $(\sqrt{2})$, so it is irrational.

Decimals that are infinite and do not eventually repeat cannot be represented as the quotient of two integers, and so are irrational.  $\pi=3.14159265....$ is a non repeating decimal, so it is irrational.
$11\pi$ is the product of a rational number $(11)$ and an irrational number ($\pi$), so it is irrational.  The product cannot be expressed as the quotient of two integers.
$6\dfrac{1}{2} , 9.0,$ and $7.11$ are rational numbers, and $11\pi$ and $\sqrt{32}$ are irrational.

question.content: **Indicate whether each number is rational or irrational.**[[☃ categorizer 1]]

hints.content: We know that rational numbers can be expressed as fractions, or as ratios of two integers.  Which of the answer choices can't be expressed that way?
$-\dfrac{13}{12}$ is already written as a fraction, so we know it is rational.
$4\dfrac{2}{3}=\dfrac{14}{3}$ , so it is also rational.
The other numbers involve radicals.  How do we determine if those are irrational?

Square roots of numbers that are perfect squares $\big($like $9=3^2$ or $16=4^2\big)$ are rational numbers, but square roots of numbers that are not perfect squares are irrational. $21$ is not a perfect square, so $\sqrt{21}$ is irrational.

**$-\sqrt{13}$, $\sqrt{55}$, and $5\pi$ are irrational numbers, and $0.5555$ and $-\dfrac{501}{502}$ are rational.**

hints.content: We know that rational numbers can be expressed as fractions, or as ratios of two integers.  Which of the answer choices can be expressed that way?

Let's multiply the numerator and denominator of $\dfrac{0.02}{0.06}$ by $100$.   We get 

$\begin{align}\frac{0.02}{0.06}&=\frac{2}{6}\\
&=\frac{1}{3},\end{align}$ 

so we know it is rational. The other numbers involve  decimals, radicals, and $\pi$. How do we determine if those types of numbers are rational?

Every real number can be expressed as a decimal. Decimals that terminate $\big($like $0.75\big)$ or eventually repeat $\big($like $0.333...=0.\overline{3}\big)$ can be represented by fractions, so they are rational. $\bigg($We can divide to see that $0.75 = \dfrac{3}{4}$ and $ 0.333...=\dfrac{1}{3}\bigg)$.

$1.732$ is a terminating decimal, so it is rational. We can also see that it's rational because it can be represented as a fraction:

 $\begin{align}1.732& = 1\frac{732}{1000}\\&=\frac{1732}{1000}.\end{align}$

Square roots of numbers that are perfect squares $\big($like $9=3^2$ or $16=4^2\big)$ are rational numbers, but square roots of numbers that are not perfect squares are irrational.  $16=4^2$ is a perfect square, so

$\begin{align}\sqrt{9+7}&=\sqrt{16}\\&=4.\end{align}$ 

$\sqrt{9+7}$ is a rational number.

Decimals that are infinite and do not eventually repeat cannot be represented as the quotient of two integers, and so are irrational.  $\pi=3.14159265....$ is a non repeating decimal, so it is irrational.
$\pi$ is irrational, and it is not a perfect square, so $\sqrt{\pi}$ is irrational.
**$\dfrac{0.02}{0.06}$ , $1.732$, and $\sqrt{9+7}$  are rational numbers, and $\sqrt{\pi}$ is irrational.**

We know $3<\pi<4$, so that $\sqrt3<\sqrt{\pi}<\sqrt4$.

  We know $\sqrt4=2$, but we don't know exactly what $\sqrt3$ is.  We *do* know $\sqrt3>1$, because $3>1$ and $\sqrt1=1$.

question.content:
The number $\pi$ is an irrational number with an infinite decimal expansion that does not repeat.  



**$\sqrt{\pi}$ is between which two consecutive integers?**


 $\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]] $<\sqrt{\pi}<$ [[☃ input-number 2]]

hints.content:
We will use the fact that if $0<a<b$, then $\sqrt a < \sqrt b$. 

We know $3<\pi<4$, so $6<{2\pi}<8$ and therefore $\sqrt6<\sqrt{2\pi}<\sqrt8$.

   We  don't know exactly what $\sqrt6$ is, but we do know $\sqrt6>2$, because $6>4$.  In a similar way, we see that $\sqrt8<3$, because $8<9$.
Therefore, we can conclude that $ 2<\sqrt {2\pi}<3$.

question.content:

**$\sqrt{2\pi}$ is between which two consecutive integers?**

 $\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]] $<\sqrt{2\pi}<$ [[☃ input-number 2]]

hints.content:
We will use the fact that if $0<a<b$, then $\sqrt a < \sqrt b$. 

We know $3<\pi<4$, so $9<{3\pi}<12$ and therefore $\sqrt9<\sqrt{3\pi}<\sqrt12$.

The first number is $3$ since $\sqrt9 = 3$.

   We  don't know exactly what $\sqrt{12}$ is, but we do know $\sqrt{12}<4$, because $12<16$.
Therefore, we can conclude that $3<\sqrt{3\pi}<4$.

question.content:
The number $\pi$ is an irrational number with an infinite decimal expansion that does not repeat.  



**$\sqrt{3\pi}$ is between which two consecutive integers?**

 $\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]] $<\sqrt{3\pi}<$ [[☃ input-number 2]]

hints.content:
We will use the fact that if $0<a<b$, then $\sqrt a < \sqrt b$. 

We know $3<\pi<4$, so 

$\qquad \dfrac{3}{2}<\dfrac{\pi}{2}<2$ and therefore $\sqrt{\dfrac{3}{2}}<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{2}}<\sqrt2$.  

We don't know exactly what $\sqrt{\dfrac{3}{2}}$ is, but we do know  $\sqrt{\dfrac{3}{2}}>1$  because $\dfrac{3}{2}>1$.  In a similar way, we see that $\sqrt2<2$, because $2<4$.
Therefore, we can conclude that $1<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{2}}<2$.

question.content:
The number $\pi$ is an irrational number with an infinite decimal expansion that does not repeat.  

**$\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{2}}$ is between which two consecutive integers?**

 $\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]] $<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{2}}<$ [[☃ input-number 2]]

hints.content:
We will use the fact that if $0<a<b$, then $\sqrt a < \sqrt b$. 

We know $3<\pi<4$, so 

$\qquad 1<\dfrac{\pi}{3}<\dfrac43$ and therefore $\sqrt{1}<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{3}}<\sqrt{\dfrac43}$.  

The first number is $1$ since $\sqrt1 = 1$.

We don't know exactly what $\sqrt{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ is, but we do know  $\sqrt{\dfrac{4}{3}}<2$  because $\dfrac{4}{3}<4$.
Therefore, we can conclude that $1<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{3}}<2$.

question.content:
The number $\pi$ is an irrational number with an infinite decimal expansion that does not repeat.  

**$\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{3}}$ is between which two consecutive integers?**

 $\qquad$[[☃ input-number 1]] $<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{3}}<$ [[☃ input-number 2]]

hints.content:
We will use the fact that if $0<a<b$, then $\sqrt a < \sqrt b$. 

We know $3<\pi<4$, so 

$\qquad \dfrac34<\dfrac{\pi}{4}<1$ and therefore $\sqrt{\dfrac34}<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}<\sqrt{1}$.  

We don't know exactly what $\sqrt{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ is, but we do know  $\sqrt{\dfrac{3}{4}}>0$  because $\dfrac{3}{4}>0$.  

The second number is $1$ since $\sqrt1 = 1$.
Therefore, we can conclude that $0<\sqrt{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}<1$.

hints.content:
We are told that John wants to make $\red{n=10}$ women's shirts and $\blue{m=5}$ men's shirts.

We can use the formula $16\red{n}+2\blue{m}^2$ to figure out how many meters of cloth John needs to buy.

Let's substitute $\red{n=10}$ and $\blue{m=5}$ into the formula $16\red{n}+2\blue{m}^2$ and evaluate.

$\begin{align*}
16\red{n}+2\blue{m}^2
 &= 16(\red{10})+2\cdot\blue{5}^2\\
 &= 16\cdot 10 +2\cdot5^{\green{2}}  \\
 &= 16 \green{\cdot} 10 +2\green{\cdot}25    \\
 &= 160 \green{+} 50 \\
 &= 210
\end{align*}$

Note the order in which we performed the operations when evaluating the expression.
First we computed the exponent $5^{\green{2}}=5\cdot 5= 25$. Then we computed the two products,
and we carried out the addition last.
John needs to buy $210$ meters of cloth.

question.content:
John sews shirts for a living. He knows the amount of cloth he needs to buy is $16n+2m^2$ meters, where $n$ is the number of women's shirts he wants to make and $m$ is the number of men's shirts he wants to make.

**How much cloth should John buy if he wants to make $10$ women's shirts and $5$ men's shirts?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] meters

hints.content:
We are given the number of red and blue candies in the bag: $\red{r=20}$ and $\blue{b=10}$.

We want to use the formula  $\dfrac{\blue{b}}{ \blue{b}+\red{r}}\,$ to find the probability of picking a blue candy from the bag.
The probability of picking a blue candy from this bag is equal to $\dfrac{1}{3} \approx 0.3333\ldots$.

question.content:
You are given a mixed bag with $r$ red candies and $b$ blue candies. If you draw a candy randomly from this bag, the probability of getting a blue candy is given by the expression $\dfrac{b}{b+r}\,$. 

**What is the probability of picking a blue candy from a bag with $10$ blue candies and $20$ red candies?**

[[☃ input-number 1]]

hints.content:
We are told that the chemist wants to make $\red{n=2}$ grams of the product $N$ and $\blue{m=40}$ grams of product $M$.

We can use the formula $5\red{n}+\dfrac{\blue{m}}{10}$ to figure out how many liters of solution she will need.

We can substitute  $\red{n=2}$ and $\blue{m=40}$ into the formula $5\red{n}+\dfrac{\blue{m}}{10}$ and evaluate the following expression:  

$\begin{align*}
5\red{n}+\dfrac{\blue{m}}{10} 
 & = 5\cdot\red{2}+\dfrac{\blue{40}}{10} \\[1mm]
 &= 5 \green{\cdot} 2 + \green{  \dfrac{40}{10} }     \\
 &= 10 \green{+} 4 \\[2mm]
 &= 14
\end{align*}$

Note the order of operations: we computed the product and the division operations first, followed by the addition operation.
The chemist will need $14$ liters of solution.

question.content:
A chemist knows she will need $5n+\dfrac{m}{10}$ liters of solution to produce $n$ grams of product $N$ and $m$ grams of product $M$.

**How many liters of solution will the chemist need if she wants to produce $2$ grams of product $N$ and $40$ grams of product $M$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] liters

hints.content: Frank's total score relative to par is the sum of the scores for the first three holes.

$
\begin{align}
\text{Total score relative to par}=& -2+(-3)+1\\\\
\end{align}$

$
\begin{align}
\phantom{\text{Total score relative to par}}
=& -2-3+1\\\\
=& -5+1\\\\
=& -4\\\\
\end{align}$
Frank's total score relative to par for the first three holes is $-4$.

question.content:

Hole | Score relative to par
:-:|:-: 
One | $-2$
Two | $-3$
Three | $+1$

hints.content:
Two expressions are equivalent to each other if they represent the same value no matter which values we choose for the variables.

To ensure this happens, we need to make the expressions match for $q$, $r$, and $t$.
Let's focus on $q$ first. Which number should go in the first box to make sure the expressions have the same value for any value of $q$?

The original expression has $5q$ in it, so a $5$ should go in the first box to make the $q$ terms match. (The $q$ is inside parentheses, but we don't have to worry about that because nothing is multiplying or dividing the parentheses).

What should go in the other boxes to make the $r$ and $t$ terms match?

The original expression has $3r$ in it, so a $3$ should go in the second box to make the $r$ terms match. (We don't worry about the parentheses here either.)

What about the third box?
There is only one $t$ in the given expression, so $1$ should go in the third box.
**Our new expression should be $(5q+3r)+1t$.**

question.content:
**Fill in the blanks to create an expression equivalent to $5q +(3r +t)$.**

(Enter an integer in each box.)
